Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the Developing Mathematical Ideas Professional Development Program: Researching its impact on teaching and student learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 3.5-year efficacy study of the Developing Mathematical Ideas (DMI) elementary math teacher professional development (PD) program. DMI was developed by staff from Education Development Center (EDC), SummerMath for Teachers, and TERC, the STEM research and development institution responsible for this research. DMI is a well-known, commercially available PD program with substantial prior evidence showing its impact on elementary teachers' mathematical and pedagogical knowledge. However, no studies have yet linked DMI directly with changes in teachers' classroom practice, or with improved student outcomes in math. This study aims to remedy this gap.

The research questions for the study are:
1) Does participation in the Developing Mathematical Ideas (DMI) professional development program lead to increases in reform-oriented teaching?
2) Does participation in DMI lead to increases in students' mathematics learning and achievement, especially in their ability to explain their thinking and justify their answers?
3) What is the process by which a reform-oriented professional development program can influence teaching practice and, thus, student learning? Through what mechanisms does DMI have impact, and with what kinds of support do we see the desired changes on our outcome measures when the larger professional development context is examined?

The dependent variables for this study include a) teachers' pedagogical and mathematics knowledge for teaching; b) the nature of their classroom practice; and c) student learning/ achievement in mathematics.

The study uses experimental and quasi-experimental methods, working with about 195 elementary grades teachers and their students in Boston, Arlington, Concord, and other Massachusetts public schools. Volunteer teachers are randomly assigned either to PD with DMI in the first year of the efficacy study, or to a control group that will wait until the second year of the study to receive DMI PD. Both groups of teachers will be followed through two academic years. Analyses use OLS regression, hierarchical modeling, and structural equation modeling, as appropriate, to compare the two groups and to track changes over time. In this way, the project explores several aspects of a conceptual framework hypothesizing relationships among PD, teacher mathematical and pedagogical knowledge, classroom teaching practice, and student outcomes. There are multiple measures of each construct, including video-analysis of teacher practice, and a new video-based measure of teacher knowledge.

The study tests the impact of DMI in a range of districts (large urban, small urban, suburban) serving an ethnically and economically diverse mix of students. It provides much needed, rigorous evidence testing the efficacy of this reform-oriented professional development program. It also directly explores the commonplace theory that teachers' understanding of content and student thinking and their encouragement of rich mathematical discourse for student sense-making lead to improvement on measures of mathematics achievement. Findings from the study are disseminated to both research and practitioner communities. The project provides professional development in mathematics to about 195 teachers to improve their ability to teach important concepts. If the evidence for efficacy is positive, then even larger-scale use of this PD program is likely.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effective teacher professional development that increases the quality of teaching and student learning can be an important tool in improving our schools. But how do we know what makes a program effective? The project, “Evaluating the Developing Mathematical Ideas (DMI) Teacher Professional Development Program: Researching its impact on teaching and student learning” (DRL-1019769) conducted a rigorous experimental and quasi-experimental study of DMI – a high quality, commercially published, math teacher professional development program – to determine its impact on teachers’ mathematical knowledge for teaching, on important elements of their teaching practice, and on student achievement.

Elementary grades teachers in nine school districts across two states signed up to participate in up to 48 hours of math teacher professional development (PD) on number and operations topics. So that we could compare impacts on teachers who received PD and their students, with impacts on similar teachers who did not receive PD and their students, teachers agreed to be randomly assigned to take the PD in the first year, or wait until the second year of the study. We collected several measures of teachers’ math knowledge for teaching at different points in the project, videotaped in classrooms each year, and collected data from assessments of students’ number and operations learning.

Our research shows that DMI has multiple direct and indirect impacts on teachers that enhance teaching and learning. Participating in DMI PD increases teachers’ math knowledge for teaching – that is, their understanding of math and how students think about mathematical ideas. It also supports teachers to engage in higher quality teaching practices – those that help keep students engaged with mathematical ideas, focused on mathematical meanings and practices, and talking about and “doing” math with one another. Some of these changes in teaching practice take time – we didn’t always see changes until a year after teachers participated in DMI PD. This means that studies that look for changes in teaching right away may not find them. Even when we didn’t find evidence that DMI directly affected teaching practices, we found that teachers with increased math knowledge for teaching are better able to enact high quality teaching practices, so DMI may have had an indirect effect in these cases. In particular, teachers with deeper understanding and interest in how students make sense of mathematical ideas, create classroom environments where students are more likely to engage in the mathematical practices described in the Common Core. Both teachers’ knowledge, and the questions they ask students make a difference.

We also found that when teachers participated in DMI, had higher math knowledge for teaching, and/ or engaged in high quality teaching practices, their students performed better on assessments of their number and operations understanding. Importantly, DMI seemed to help teachers use their math knowledge for teaching to better support student learning. Comparing teachers with the same level of math knowledge, those who had participated in DMI PD had students with higher achievement scores than those who had not yet been in the PD. Similarly, participating in DMI seems to help teachers leverage certain high quality teaching practices into higher student achievement scores. Again, even when DMI doesn’t have a direct effect on student achievement, it seems to help teachers use other things they’ve learned more effectively.

In the course of conducting this research, the project also developed a number of research instruments and rubrics, provided DMI PD to dozens of teachers, and disseminated its findings.

Lots of resources are devoted to providing professional development for teachers in the hopes that this will make a difference in teaching practice and student achievement; although some doubt the value of these expenditures. This study provides evidence that high quality math professional development can make a difference in teaching and learning. To do so, it should a) deepen teachers’ knowledge of math and how students think about math, b) deepen their ability to lead student discourse about mathematical ideas so that students can express and explore their thinking and reasoning around mathematical ideas, and c) enhance their ability to create classroom environments where students are consistently engaged with mathematical ideas, practices, and one another. If schools can provide such PD to teachers, then we may be able to improve mathematics education across the US.
